title: engineer sues ex boss for 1m for farting on him
story: David Hingst, from Melbourne, Australia, sued his former employer Construction Engineering for bullying after his supervisor would lt his bum and fart” on him at work.He told the court “flatulence was a form of bullying” and that his ex-colleague Greg Short was a serial farter, AAP reported.As a result of the constant farting, Mr Hingst, , sprayed deodorant on Mr Short and called him “Mr Stinky”.Hingst said: I would be sitting with my face to the wall and he would come into the room, which was small and had no windows.“He would fart behind me and walk away. He would do this five or six times a day.”Mr Hingst said the flatulence had caused him “severe stress” and is seeking .millionin compensation.The case was thrown out by the Supreme Court of Victoria last April but Hingst is appealing the decision.Justice Rita Zammit found that eventhe farting occurred it “would not necessarily amount to bullying”.The case came before the Court of Appeal on Monday.At the original hearing, Mr Short said he didn’t remember doing it “but I may have done it once or twice, maybe”.He said: “I don’t recall doing so, so I’m not flat out saying I didn’t or I did. I just can’t remember doing it. Buthe alleges I did it.”But Mr Short denied he was doing it “with the intention of distressing or harassing” Mr Hingst.Another former employee, Phillip Hamilton, told the court he recalled times Mr Hingst “got quite offended by some of the stuff that went on”.Mr Hamilton said: “Obviously there were incidences wherehad a propensity to walk over to the printer, which was next to me and I thinksat behind where the printer was andwould flatulate , he would fart you know, and that would happen quite frequently..On Monday, Mr Hingst reiterated his farting claims, saying “He thrusted his bum at me while he’s at work.“And you sprayed deodorant at him,” Justice Phillip Priest said.Justice Priest said farts were not the key issue in Mr Hingst’s original claim, as it had focused more on alleged bullying phone calls.Hingst claimed Mr Short’s behaviour was part of a conspiracy to get rid of him and said his time at Construction Engineering caused him psychiatric injuries.Mr Hingst, who has represented himself throughout the trial and appeal, is seeking leave to appeal on several grounds.He claims he didn’t get a fair trial as he felt under pressure from Justice Zammit when questioning witnesses. He also felt the judge was biased against him.But Justice Priest said the trial judge seemed to show “remarkable latitude” to Mr Hingst during the -day proceedings.“The very distinct impression I get is you were given every opportunity to put your case,” he said.The Court of Appeal judges will deliver their ruling on the appeal on Friday.A version of this story originally appeared on News.com.au

title: shocking moment man chases people with meat cleaver on dublin housing estate after two cars and flat set alight
story: The incident began at around .pm when the apartment went up in flames in the Newtown Court area of Coolock in north Dublin.Around half an hour later, two cars parked outside a home in the Temple View Green estate in Clarehall, a five minute drive away, went ablaze too.Videos shared across social media showed large plumes of black smoke as the vehicles perished in the driveway.Stunned neighbours can be seen in the distance, with some taking videos.Another video shows a hooded man chasing another while brandishing the meat cleaver in his right hand.The man first takes cover behind a red van before the attacker starts to punch the van.He chases the man around a car for less than a minute before walking away.There was also another man pictured in the background but is not seen to be involved.The person taking the video is heard saying: “Holy f***... meat cleaver, someone’s going to die. title: jack shepherd faces extradition hearing georgia
story: Jack Shepherd, , had spent months on the run after being found guilty of the -year-old womans manslaughter - finally handing himself into authorities in Georgia in January this year.Charlotte, , was killed when Shepherds speedboat crashed on the Thames in .The web designer had fled the UK before his trial that saw him sentenced in his absence to six years in prison.He today faces a hearing that could see him sent back to the UK to face justice after his lawyers revealed he had abandoned his extradition fight.Charlottes father Graham Brown said: Overall, I think we are pleased that finally its coming to an end and we seem to be getting the justice we think we deserve for Charlotte.Depending on the outcome of todays hearing, Shepherd could be back in the UK as soon as Friday.Shepherd has always maintained his innocence, claiming it was a tragic accident.As he handed himself into authorities, the smirking killer said: I hope justice will prevail and my appeal will be successful so everyone can move forward with their lives.During the manslaughter trial, the court heard Shepherds speedboat had defects when it crashed on the Thames.The -year-old had previously said he did not want toto the UK, claiming he had received death threats.He was held in a special unit in Georgia while waiting for the extradition case to be prepared.His Georgian lawyer Mariam Kublashvili has said he regretted his decision not to appear at the Old Bailey trial over the -year-old womans death.

title: blow for theresa may as remainer mps seize control of brexit process and get to have their say on what happens next
story: The PM lost a crunch amendment vote in Parliament by  votes to  in another crushing defeat and at least three ministers have quit so they can defy her.The amendment, pushed by Sir Oliver Letwin, will let them decide on what kind of EU exit they want by putting down their own options. It will mean that wounded Mrs May is forced to hand over control of the order paper to them on Wednesday to try and work out a way forward.In another extraordinary night in the House of Commons:Brexiteer Suella Braverman told BBC Newsnight: Tonight weve seen a Parliamentary massacre.Priti Patel said it was another example of the political class promising one thing and delivering another.Trust in politics is broken, she said.And almost immediately MPs who want a second referendum called yet again for Parliament to overturn the result of the historic  referendum vote.A spokesman for the Brexit department said this evening it was disappointing to see the amendment pass, and pleaded with MPs to come to a realistic outcome when the Commons debates the way forward in just two days time.They added: This amendment instead upends the balance between our democratic institutions and sets a dangerous, unpredictable precedent for the future.While it is now up to Parliament to set out next steps in respect of this amendment, the Government will continue to call for realism – any options considered must be deliverable in negotiations with the EU.Parliament should take account of how long these negotiations would take, andthey’d require a longer extension which would mean holding European Parliamentary elections.Jeremy Corbyn congratulated the House of Commons for taking control off the PM and throwing Parliament into more chaos, and said: Where this government has failed this House has and must, succeed.And EU boss Guy Verhofstadt praised tonights news, tweeting: An opportunity to build a cross-party cooperation leading to an enhanced political declaration and a closer future relationship!Today the PM refused to back Sir Olivers plan for a series of so-called indicative votes, saying she was sceptical that such a plan would ever work.When we have tried this kind of thing in the past, it has produced contradictory outcomes or no outcome at all, she told MPs earlier.There is a further risk when it comes to Brexit, as the UK is only one half of the equation and the votes could lead to an outcome that is unnegotiable with the EU.MPs could end up forcing through a second referendum or even try to reverse Brexit altogether.The PM promised never to give a blank cheque to commit to an outcome without knowing what it is.However, she tried to see off the rebellion by promising to engage constructively with this process.David Lidington said this evening that the Government would bring forward similar votes this week but refused to go into more detail, which wasnt then enough to win MPs over.Alternative Brexit options are expected to include a number of softer options including:But any softer Brexit option risks destroying the Conservative party.The PM said still planning to bring her deal back to the Commons for a third time, possibly after showing Brexiteers what the risk would be in an attempt to force them to vote for her deal.But theres not enough support to bring it back as things stand at the moment.Today Tory MPs called for her to step down, evenshe does get her deal through Parliament in the next few days.Leave-backing MP Rachel Maclean warned today that the Commons can only unite around a position that bears little or no resemblance to what Leave voters voted for.She added: This is why I have consistently voted for the WA to end this turmoil, and get us out of the EU, as I could see this coming a mile off.But that would lead to a y extension while Parliament figures out another plan, the PM warned today.A slow Brexit which extends Article  beyond nd May, forces the British people to take part in European Elections and gives up control of any of our borders, laws, money or trade is not a Brexit that will bring the British people together, she said.FOR the first time in more than a hundred years the Government wont be controlling what happens in the House of Commons on Wednesday.Tonight MPs voted to withdraw an obscure procedure from them and hand back control to MPs.Sir Oliver Letwins amendment, which passed and then was later confirmed in two crushing defeats for the PM, will let MPs have a say on what kind of Brexit they want to see.It will mean that there can be a series of votes on Wednesday on other options aside from Mrs Mays deal - on anything MPs want.The Speaker has a considerable amount of power in this situation, according to Sir Olivers plan.He will choose what motions to be put forward and lead MPs to vote on their preferred Brexit options.But his plan doesnt force the Government to actually take on board whatever MPs say they want.It will instead put it forward with a view to the Government putting forward a plan for the House to debate and vote on in future.Mrs May had argued she would give MPs the time to do this on her terms, but her promises were not enough to persuade dozens of Tories to defy her tonight.I hope we can all agree, we are now at the moment of decision.And in doing so we must confront the reality of the hard choices before us.The PM appeared to totally kill off leaving without a deal, telling MPs: Unless this House agrees to it, No Deal will not happen.No Brexit must not happen.

title: i lost virginity alien
story: However, he claims in reality the occasion was a little more out of this world -  insisting he lost his virginity to a busty alien called Crescent.While alien abduction might sound unbelievable to most of us, up to six per cent of the population believe they have been abducted by alien, and recently experts have been exploring the new theory aliens do exist - but were just too stupid to handle it.According to The Times, scientists are considering the possibility aliens are keeping their existence quiet - because were too primitive compared to them.Those who claim they have had encounters often claim that they are ‘taken’ so that aliens can take their sperm and eggs to create a new ‘hybrid’ race, targeting the same families to harvest their genetic specic material.Here, The Sun Online meets three people who bizarrely claim they have the proof that aliens do exist.David Huggins, , was living on his parents farm in Georgia, America, when he says he was seduced by a big-breasted alien woman as he was walking through the woods.“I thought,anything, I’d be losing [my virginity] in the backseat of a Ford—something like that. I never knew what they were and I didn’t know why they were in my room or what they did with me.However, the mum-of-two, who lives in the southwest of France, didnt realise what this meant until she was hypnotised in .She continues: I recognised I had been abducted by extra-terrestrials throughout my le.Throughout my le Id been left with unexplained marks on my body.One time I had three coin shaped bruises on my thigh that formed a triangle, and on another occasion I had a throbbing pain in my right side close to my kidney.It was only thanks to hypnosis I realised that the pain was a result of the probes they had used inside me.After her encounters, Myriame became the head of CeroFrance, an association created in  which holds regular meet ups for those who claim to have been abducted by extra-terrestrials.Many of us are terried by what have happened, she continues. Some have lost their jobs and lost their marriage. They are very disturbed by what’s happened. But together we can safely talk about what has happened to us.The members of the group have much in common: many say they have had their oian eggs or sperm removed or harvested, some also say they have been abducted since childhood.According to CeroFrance members, aliens target the same families multiple times.Why are we taken  It’s the big question, Myriame adds.I don’t know why we’ve been selected. Some of us think it might be easier for them to perform their procedures and operations on us.We know they follow family lines. My parents have been abducted. My children in their childhood were taken too.Each time I was abducted a probe would enter my body and my oian eggs were removed. I was powerless to stop it.When I was in therapy I was able to discover that the aliens viewed humans as a brutal destructive and suicidal race. That we are destroying our planet and our governments are crazy.So they are creating a new race of species with a dferent civilisation.While encounters are often scoffed at for being outlandish or unbelievable, all the victims say its happened more than once.The most profound abduction happened to me when I was staying at my employer’s apartment in the French Alps, says Myriame.It was on the sixth floor I was in bed enjoying the view of the stars through the ceiling window. I began to doze off so I turned off the light.That’s when I heard a click. The room suddenly lit up and I saw the window was open and a cable was hanging down. I couldn’t move. I was paralysed in bed.When I came round I was on a metallic table. There was a soft fabric over me and it was hard to breathe - I could hear the movement of surgical instruments and machines.Then the cable entered my body. I tried to fight it but I couldn’t. Little grey aliens were all around me and there was a large insect alien too.Eventually I opened my eyes and I was back in the bedroom, it was dark and the window was closed – there was no one there, but there was a heavy atmosphere in the room.I couldn’t sleep in the apartment again and checked into a hotel for the rest of my stay. I had an awful lower abdomen pain afterwards.Myriame claims she kept her experiences and fears to herself. She only remembered what happened to her because of the hypnosis she underwent seven years ago.She explains it is ‘traumatising’ to live through the experience of being taken - she also believes the aliens communicate with her via telepathy.The extra-terrestrials don’t want us to remember what happens to us when we are taken so they try and mask our memories, she adds.When I remembered the second time, I recalled being in bed. There was no roof on the house - instead there was a massive round circle above and I saw a red net coming for me.The red net took me back to the dome room and again they harvested my eggs.After I understood what had happened to me – I was much calmer. I wasn’t going mad. It’s something people don’t talk about for fear of others thinking they are crazy.Like Myriame, Gerry Battles from Co Limerick, says he was dazzled by bright light before being abducted onto a ship by an alien with a big cone head and beautul, ginormous eyes who communicated to him telepathically in December .Garry believes he was sent back to pass on a message that in over  years time a giant asteroid the size of  the Irish province Munster is going to obliterate our planet.The asteroid will approach your planet from the th Quadrant, according to his alien abductor.Hilary Porter,  - who claims she was first abducted in the s when she was just five - agrees with the theory aliens want to create a hybrid race.After years of research following an abduction that she claims left her with triangular suction marks on my stomach, blood suction marks, Hilary believes aliens target certain human “tribes” whose genetic make-up is of more interest.“The Celtic tribes from Wales, Scotland, Ireland, Cornwall and Brittany are definitely on the list,” she says.“They are trying to make alien human hybrids and it seems the genetic material of these races are more compatible.”Typically after an abduction Hilary suffers migraines, and wakes up with bruising or bloody marks on her clothes or bed sheets.Sceptics rationalise abductees experiences as everything from sleep paralysis to  memory syndrome, but there is no definitive answer to explain what abductees are experiencing.Psychologist Nicolas Dumont has spent seven years speaking to  abductees in France.There isn’t a typical profile, he says. We often see all forms of personalities, from those who have never heard of aliens, to those who have as a child been fascinated by space.There is no distinction across the social classes either. I’ve seen professionals, farm workers, scientists – it’s a broad range.He is open-minded about the alien experiences.If you’re sceptical it is easier to dismiss these experiences as psychiatric problems or sleep paralysis, he adds.I’m open to it. I listen to their experiences.They have marks on their body. They have seen things around their home. We’re finding that they often report a spiritual change too: they have visions or even develop psychic powers.One woman was inexplicably cured of cancer. She had a brain tumour which covered her temporal lobe in her brain like a spider’s web. After an abduction, the tumour completely disappeared.Her brain has been scanned but we found no trace of it. We don’t have a scientic explanation for this.Nicolas says that while he sees more female abductees than men – this is normal throughout all psychological consultations.Women are more likely to contact and want to talk. Men keep it inside. They worry people will think they’re mad or paranoid.According to Nicolas, abductees talk about six dferent species of aliens.The little grey ones are popular sightings and they tend to be the ‘workers, Nicolas explains. They have a distinct job during these abductions.We also know of the tall white ones that oversee what’s going on. title: brexit 5 fast facts you
story: NewsBrexit:  fast facts you need this morning as MPs seize control from Theresa MayOur Prime Minister is in office but not in power - and we still dont know how Brexit will end. Here is what you need to know this Tuesday morningShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video watch-moment-commons-votes-take-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is in office but not in power today after losing control of the Brexit process. MPs held a historic, unprecedented vote last night to oversee the Parliamentary timetable themselves. And they will use it to hold indicative votes to finally flesh out what MPs want to do next with Brexit. Just  days before the EUaposs April  deadline to leave or face a long extension, we still donapost know what Parliament wants. But we may soon find out, with votes due to be held tomorrow night - and theyaposll take shape throughout the day. Here are  fast facts you need this morning.  Theresa May lost control of Brexit last night in a damning defeat for the Prime Minister.MPs voted - to take ownership of the Commons schedule in an unprecedented parliamentary defeat. They backed a plan by Tory veteran Sir Oliver Letwin that will allow MPs to control business from pm tomorrow in the House of Commons. They are due to use the power to hold a string of “indicative votes” on the next steps for leaving the EU. Mrs May didnapost just lose control of Brexit, but also her party.  Tory rebels voted against the government. The government issued a furious statement branding last nightaposs vote a dangerous, unpredictable precedent.  Under the plan, Parliament will now start staging aposindicative votesapos on the future for Brexit from pm tomorrow. MPs are expected to bring forward competing options such as a customs union or second referendum, and vote on pink slips of paper for any that they could potentially back. Architect Hilary Benn, of the Commons Brexit Committee, said at this stage he wouldnapost press for a apospreferentialapos vote, but instead tot up the total support for each option. At a later date they could be whittled down. But the process is still unclear. And thataposs why all eyes are on the MPs, who will work out the process in more detail today. Thereaposs a huge catch though. Theresa May has made clear she could ignore whatever MPs vote for - and she vowed not to give a “blank cheque” of government support. Whatever happens, the UK must come up with its next steps by April  and agree either a deal or a longer extension with the EU, or revoke Article . Otherwise, we will crash out with no deal.  Backers believe last nightaposs vote is just the start, and could well lead to a softer Brexit being implemented. Steve Brine, who resigned as a Business Minister to oppose the government, told the BBC it would focus some minds adding: Those on my side who donapost like the deal, maybe they will realise that the House of Commons is prepared to act. And, anything from here, as far as they are concerned, gets softer in terms of Brexit. Indicative votes will be non-binding, buttheyaposre ignored, Tory rebel Nick Boles warned MPs could take the next step of legislating against Theresa Mayaposs will. Mr Boles said last night: We will be relying on the Government to reflect Parliamentaposs wishes. If, ultimately, the Government refuses to listen to what Parliament has voted for then we will look to bring forward a Bill, pass an Act of Parliament that will require the Government to reflect Parliamentaposs wishes in its new negotiating mandate. A government spokesman said it would “continue to call for realism – any options considered must be deliverable in negotiations with the EU. They added: Parliament should take account of how long these negotiations would take, andthey’d require a longer extension which would mean holding European Parliamentary elections.  In a damning indictment, three ministers voted to take power away from their own government and put it in the hands of MPs. Therefore those ministers - Alistair Burt, Richard Harrington and Steve Brine - all had to resign. In a blistering letter, Business Minister Mr Harrington - who had threatened to resign for months - accused the government of “playing roulette with the lives and livelihoods of the vast majority of people in this country.” He added the Brexit chaos has led to “a sense of ridicule for British business across the world. And he condemned the refusal to rule out the nonsense of No Deal, saying Theresa May could not pursue her plan at the price of suicide. More ministers could follow tomorrowTheresa May refuses to allow free votes in the aposindicativeapos process. Remainer Cabinet ministers will be demanding a free vote in todayaposs Cabinet meeting from .am. . Theresa May’s Brexit deal finally looks dead - but it could still rise from the ashes  The Prime Minister’s Brexit deal has already been twice defeated in the House of Commons. Finally she confirmed she would not bring it back today, admitting there was not enough support for a third roll of the dice. At the time she insisted she would still try and hold a third “meaningful vote” on the deal this week. Now MPs have voted to take control of the process, the focus has shted away from her third deal. But some may be privately hoping that last nightaposs dramatic move will force Tory Brexiteers and the DUP to come on side. The government has until Thursday to hold a third meaningful voteit wants to secure an Brexit extension to May . Otherwise weaposre in sudden death time to April .

title: brexit plans tatters theresa refuses
story: NewsBrexit plans are in tatters but Theresa May refuses to admit her deal is deadThe Prime Minister has come under mounting pressure to come up with a Plan B after her Brexit plans hit the buffersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAR NewsLabour have accused Theresa May of losing control of her deal, the Tories and Parliament"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May has been placed under mounting pressure to admit her doomed Brexit deal is dead and to come up with a plan B.Despite the deadline looming, the Prime Minister was still unable to set out a way forward.Labour accused her of “losing control” of her deal, the Tories and Parliament.Mrs May pulled a third vote on her deal, but did not say when – or even– it would take place at some point. She also failed to confirm whether she would accept the resultMPs agreed an alternative way forward.  And while she insisted that a no-deal Brexit was off the table, No officials then said it was not. Mrs May faced more calls from Tories to quit while Parliament plotted to wrestle the Brexit process away from Government. Several Remainer ­ministers were on the brink of quitting to back the plan after the Government confirmed it would oppose the vote. Her failure of leadership amid the crisis infuriated MPs. One of her Cabinet ministers said: “It’s extraordinary that at this crucial stage we still don’t know what is going on.” The UK has been given until April  to agree a deal, then must either crash out of the EU or delay for an alternative plan. Before tonight’s voting , Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer told the Commons: “The PM has lost control of the meaningful vote. “She has no idea when it might be put or whether it is winnable. “She has lost control of the negotiations… The PM also appears to have lost control of her party. And today she is likely to lose control of Parliament.” Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the PM must accept her deal will never be approved, and that she must look for alternatives.He said: “Given the Prime Minister admitted she does not have the numbers for her deal, will she accept today her deal is dead and the House should not have its time wasted giving the same answer for a third time ” He called on Mrs May to support plans for indicative votes. He said: “Rather than trying to ­engineer a way to bring back the same twice-rejected deal, will the Prime Minister instead allow, rather than fight, plans for indicative votes  She cannot both accept her deal does not have the numbers and stand in the way of finding an alternative that may have the numbers.”    Mrs May defended her opposition to Tory MP Sir Oliver Letwin’s plan for MPs to take control of the Parliamentary timetable. “No Government could give a blank cheque to commit to an outcome without knowing what it is,” she said. Sir Oliver plans to take over the timetable for days, even instructing the Government to go back to Brussels with a new plan. DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds said “there were big gaps” between what they want and what the deal offers.    Mrs May told MPs it was with “great regret” she felt “as things stand” there was still not sufficient support to bring her deal back for a third vote. She also infuriated hardline Brexiteers by saying their preferred no-deal exit was no longer an option. She angered the DUP by suggesting no-deal would be so damaging for Northern Ireland no PM could allow it. But within moments of making her remarks, Downing Street officials were rowing back. MPs will tomorrow get a vote to delay Brexit Day to April ,a deal isn’t passed, or to May it is. A Government source said an election might be “the only way out of this”. Senior eurosceptics who visited the PM at Chequers over the weekend have allegedly called themselves the Grand Wizards, apparently without realising it refers to the Ku Klux Klan.

story: NewsEU No Deal Brexit plans COMPLETED with major changesyoure going on holidayBrits face a torrent of new checks at the border in No Deal Brexit after the EU confirmed its plan - warning the situation is "increasingly likely" and will cause "signicant disruption"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video leo-adkar-discusses-irish-border-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrit holidaymakers face a torrent of new checks at the border in a No Deal Brexit after the EU completed its emergency plan - and said No Deal is increasingly likely. European Commission chiefs warned of signicant disruption today as they signed off a flood of documents outlining what will happenthe UK crashes out on the newly-delayed date of April . UK travellers wonapost need a visa for trips of less than  days, as long as the plan is adopted by EU leaders and the European Parliament. But passports will need at least three monthsapos validity beyond the end of the trip, and canapost be used in EU lanes at airports in No Deal. Brits will also be asked for theirand purpose of stay - and to have the existence of sufficient means of subsistence to ensure they can fund their .    Much of the information was first outlined in November, but the EU highlighted it today saying its plans are now completed and No Deal is increasingly likely. An EU official told reporters France, the Netherlands and Belgium have set up  new border posts and hired , customs officer to cope. In a statement, the Commission warned of signicant disruption for citizens and businessesthere is no deal. The EU warned: UK citizens will no longer be citizens of the European Union. They will be subject to additional checks when crossing borders into the European Union. Again, Member States have made considerable preparations at ports and airports to ensure that these checks are done as efficiently as possible, but they may nevertheless cause delays.    An EU document added: Travellers are advised to take account of possible delays at border posts as of the withdrawal date. It comes as MPs prepare to vote on what type of Brexit theyaposd like, more than , days after the referendum and weeks before weaposre meant to leave. So-called aposindicative votesapos will be held on Wednesdaya bid to hold them passes in the House of Commons tonight. Meanwhile Theresa May dumped plans for a third vote on her Brexit deal tomorrow amid fears it would not pass. If the deal passes by Friday, the UK will leave the EU on a later date of May , giving enough time for laws to be in place.    The EU has published  preparedness notices which are similar to just over  published by the UK government in case of No Deal. Meanwhile pets will be badly hit as the EUaposs pet passports become invalid for UK travellers after April ,there is No Deal. And the EU documents confirm pet owners will need a third country pet passport.  The EUaposs documents also confirm what most already knew - that the UK will enjoy no transition periodthereaposs a No Deal Brexit. That contradicts Boris Johnson, who even today called for an implementation period in a No Deal Brexit until . And the EU confirmed mobile phone giants will be free to bring back roaming charges for UK travellers - something that was already known in the UK. story: NewsBrexit: Savage poll shows % think Theresa Mays government has handled it wellFindings from a National Centre for Social Research study make unhappy reading for the Prime MinisterShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMore grim news for the PM "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBeleaguered Theresa May is dealt another blow today as voters hammer her handling of Brexit negotiations. Newport Crown Court heard Gaut had moved into a flat next door to Harleyaposs friend David Osborne in the village of New Tredegar, Gwent, after being released from prison. title: dramatic images reveal terrifying pace
story: NewsDramatic images reveal the terrying pace Britains coastline is shrinkingIn some parts of the UK more than half a mile has been lost from the coast in the last  yearsShareCommentsByEmilia Bruce-WattJane Lavender:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSeveral homes have fallen into the sea already in Happisburgh, Norfolk "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChilling photos have revealed the increasingly rapid pace Britainaposs coastline is shrinking . In some cases the coastline has dropped back by as much as half a mile. Dozens of homes have also been lost as beaches are eroded across the country. One man, photographer Mike Page, has been documenting the dramatic erosion over the last three decades - and his shots show just how serious the situation really is. The -year-oldaposs aerial photos, which show the land along the coast of East Anglia, have even caught the moment some homes fell into the sea.    The images show how Norfolk and Suffolkaposs beaches have shrunk between  and now as chunks of land the size of football fields crumble into the water.  Mike, a retired mechanic, said: Itaposs an ongoing issue and we will see a lot more of this. Iaposve been looking at the erosion for some time now so I knew it would look something like this but it is quite unbelievable - itaposs a lot and itaposs getting worse. There is going to be more land lost. It will just get worse - they are losing areas that they didnapost expect to lose. They didnapost think it would be that quick. They have lost about  houses at Happisburgh and about  houses at Hemsby.    I grew up in the Beccles area and they have lost about half a mile of coast - that has been since I was about  or  years old. I frequented that area often when I was young and everything has gone now. Mike flies above the coastline in a two seater Cessna  and takes the photos with a handheld cannon D and D, observing the erosion from a unique viewpoint. He added: People use drones now to get a view of the coast but they still canapost get the height that we can. It is a serious issue and land owners are spending their own money protecting their land.  The government will not spend the money on it. People are having to spend money on dismantling their own houses. They cannot allow any rubbish to fall into the sea and they are having to pay for that themselves - it is costing people a fortune and is ruining livelihoods. In Hemsby, they lost land over just two or three weeks after a big storm - the coast is made of sand and the erosion happens very, very quickly. The only way to stop it is to get rock barriers at the coastsapos bases. They have done this at some points and it it did stop the erosion for a period of time. If the government spent the money orcommunities could raise the money for the rock barriers, the erosion wouldnapost be as quick - but itaposs hard for them to do that.  This stretch of coast is being allowed to erode under a government policy called “managed realignment”, which allows the shoreline to move naturally. It means communities will be given time to move with some sea defences put in place but ultimately nature will be allowed to take its course. The Norfolk and Suffolk coastline also holds historical signicance and archaeologists treasure these shores. The sandy heathland of Easton Bavents, near Southwold in Suffolk was once England’s most easterly point back in the days when it extended a mile out to sea. Happisburgh, near Norwich, in Norfolk, is the earliest known human settlement in Europe, but a after one million years, humans are now retreating in land.  In , residents of Beach Road in Happisburgh were asked to leave their homes as the waves began to creep ever closer. But campaigner Bryony ­Nierop-Reading, , refused, and moved out three years later - only when her bathroom and bedroom were hanging over the clf edge. The Environment Agency estimates that , properties in Britain will be lost to the sea over the next century. Mike has taken , images in his  years of flying and has captured moments in time that will never be seen again.

By contrast, their own mums are far less likely to have tried the same tasks, while their grandmothers would certainly have left these ‘blue jobs’ to the man of the house. The research was conducted by Yale, in conjunction with their ‘Spring into Action’ campaign which offers tips and advice for those wanting to make a change to their homes during the peak DIY season.    Stephen Roberts, marketing manager for Yale said: “Looking at the stats between the age groups, it is clear to see women today are far more hands on than their mothers and grandmothers ever were. “And although not all women feel one hundred per cent comfortable tackling skilled DIY tasks, they are far more likely to give it a go than previous generations. “Surprisingly, many younger women don’t remember their grandmothers even going as far as unclogging a toilet or planting a tree.” The study found almost half of today’s women are happy to assemble furniture, compared to just  per cent of their mums, and seven per cent of their grandmothers. Four in  young females are comfortable hanging blinds or curtains, in contrast to just  per cent of grandparents.  And while replacing door knobs is easy for a third of ladies today, only  per cent of their mums and eight per cent of grandmothers would have given the same job a try. The only areas of DIY where previous generations excel are hanging wallpapers, fixing wallpaper seams – possibly due to the trend in painted walls these days - and changing a fuse. Interestingly, the OnePoll study indicated that while women are proficient at a host of DIY tasks, fitting an alarm to the house isn’t one of them. Just one in  women claim this is a task they’d feel comfortable doing, with just  per cent of women accepting responsibility for their own home’s security. Roberts added: “The findings regarding home security came as somewhat of a shock – particularly as women are willing and able to tackle numerous other jobs around the home. “For some reason home security is still considered to be a blue job, and yet fitting security products is easier than ever thanks to wireless systems and app-controlled technology.”    Researchers also found  per cent of those polled are confident tackling DIY tasks around the home – and only six per cent would avoid the DIY altogether. Just one in  women of today agree that some DIY jobs are for men and some are for women – believing tasks such as fixing a toilet, fitting an alarm and re-tiling a roof should be taken on by the man of the house. Six in  believe choosing curtains should be a job firmly left to women, while  per cent prefer to be the ones to pick the carpets and the same percentage think ladies should be in charge of planting flowers in the garden. Women of today feel more able to take on DIY projects than generations before them as there are more online guides to helpand there are YouTube tutorials which didn’t exist years ago . One fth feel they have more people they can ask for help these days, and  per cent have grown up doing jobs for themselves. But they believe for previous generations, it was always assumed DIY was a man’s joband  per cent lacked the skill set required. story: NewsStudent, , who put up with death smell makes horrying discovery in showerSeren Gomez says the stench was like "dirty water" and a "food bin" before it got worse and she decided to investigateShareCommentsByChris kitchingKate McMullin:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video death-smell-student-house-led-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young student says she put up with a death smell in her new build flat for months only to make a horrying discovery under her shower. Seren Gomez said she was left disgusted after finally investigating the putrid stench and finding a rotting rat carcass behind a  as her flat became infested with flies. Initially, the foul odour smelled like dirty water and a food bin, but it gradually got worse, the -year-old Liverpool John Moores University student said. Ms Gomez, from South Wales, told the Liverpool Echo that the smell was so bad that she wouldnapost bring anyone into her £-a-week deluxe studio apartment because she was too embarrassed.    A few weeks after she moved in last September, she said, the flat began to smell like there was something dead inside it. Ms Gomez, who is studying a masters degree in forensic bioscience, said: The smell just kept getting worse and worse. At first it smelled like dirty water, then it was like a food bin. I couldnapost bring anyone to the studio because the smell was so bad, it was embarrassing.    I had to light candles and incense burners to try and mask the smell. I study decomposition as part of my masters so I know what it smells like. People thought I was crazy because I would say aposit smells like there is something dead in my houseapos. Ms Gomez said she complained about the stench to Trophy Homes, contractors employed by the propertyaposs owners. She said she sent footage which showed flies and captured the sound of rats in the walls.  When a maintenance worker arrived to change a lightbulb she asked him to remove the shower . They found a rotting rat carcass, Ms Gomez said. She added: I didnapost want to take the  off myself because it would be classed as damage to the property. So I asked the maintenance man to do it and just said aposI think there is something dead under thereapos. And when he took it off - there was a dead rat and the smell was absolutely awful.  At that point I was actually happy that there was something there, because I had been saying it for so long. Ms Gomez said the situation affected her mental health and she almost dropped out of her masters to move back home. She said: I would expect thisI was paying £ a week but I am paying almost £ to live in a deluxe studio. A spokesperson for Trophy Homes said: “We were asked by the landlord to attend the property and investigate what had been reported as a drainage problem. “We did all we could to find the root of the issue, particularly as this is a new build property and the tenant is the first resident. “Both specialist drainage and pest control contractors visited the property on separate occasions and were unable to pin-point the underlying cause.  Meanwhile we also worked closely with Liverpool Student Homes as we sought a swt resolution. “When the rodent was eventually recovered by our own contractor it was removed and dealt with immediately.  “We understand the landlord has since offered to move the tenant immediately to another studio - an offer which has been declined.” How to get rid of rats  The common, brown or Norway rat, also known as the sewer rat, is prevalent across the whole of the UK, says the British Pest Control Association . They often weigh over half a kilo and measure about cm inwithout counting the tail. Each female may produce from three to  litters of between six and eight young in a year, the BPCA says. The rats can cause signicant damage to woodwork, plastic, bricks and lead pipes in homes, and strip insulation from electrical cables, increasing the risk of a fire.  And they carry many nasty diseases - including leptospirosis or Weilaposs disease, salmonella, listeria, toxoplasma gondii and hantavirus - which can spread to humans. To prevent an infestation, property owners should seal gaps around pipes and under sheds, remove potential nesting sites by keeping yards and gardens clean and tidy, keep drain inspection covers in a good state of repair, and cover household waste and compost bins. To get rid of rats, the BPCA suggests contacting a professional pest control company which has access to rodenticides not available to the public. For those who decide to carry out the work themselves, poisons and traps can be purchased from hardware stores or garden centres. The BPCA warns: When placing poison or traps, make sure they are in a safe and secure place out of reach of children and pets. When using rodenticides always follow the instructions on the label, and importantly search for and dispose of any dead rodents in a safe manner.

title: mums working night shifts are
story: NewsMums-to-be working night shts are a third more likely to suffer miscarriagesPregnant women working two or more nights a week are  per cent more likely to lose their babies the following week, according to a studyShareCommentsByIsabel DobinsonTfany Lo:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsPregnant women who work two or more late shts a week have a higher risk of miscarriage "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPregnant women who work night shts are nearly a third more likely to suffer a miscarriage, scientists have warned. And it might be down to a lack of light, leading to low levels of melatonin which disrupts the body clock. Danish researchers who analysed the working lives of more than , expecting women said the dangers of miscarrying dramatically increase the more night shts pregnant women work. According to the study, women who work two or more nights a week are  per cent more likely to suffer a miscarriage the following week and the risk is becomes greater after week eight. Almost , of the women who took part in the survey suffered a miscarriage during the six year period.    Doctor Luise Moelenberg Begtrup, of the Bispebjerg and Frederiksberg Hospital in Cophenhagen, said the groundbreaking results is of national importance because  per cent of pregnant women work at least one night sht a month. She said: Observational studies indicate an association between working nights and miscarriage, but inaccurate exposure assessment precludes causal inference. Using payroll data with exact and prospective measurement of night work, the objective was to investigate whether working night shts during pregnancy increases the risk of miscarriage. This may be explained by the decline in the proportion of chromosomally abnormal foetuses with gestational age. This makes an association with environmental exposure more easily detectable among later miscarriages. The results could have implications for national occupational health regulations.    The researchers observed the working lives of , women from five dferent regions across a six year period. Almost half of the women worked nine night shts throughout their pregnancy and eight per cent of the thousands surveyed suffered a miscarriage. The report published in journal, Occupational  Environmental Medicine focused on Danish women working in the public sector including hospitals. It is the first to analyse womenaposs payroll data and assess how risk of miscarriage increases over time. Scientists linked payroll data to national registers on birth and hospital admissions for miscarriage to determine how the risk of miscarriage between weeks four to  of pregnancy was influenced by night work. After week eight of pregnancy, pregnant women who worked two or more night shts the previous week had a  per cent higher risk of miscarriage compared to women who did not work any night shts that week. It was also discovered that the risk of miscarriage increased the more night shts worked and how regular women worked nights. Researchers are yet to determine a direct cause of the link but they suspect women being exposed to light during the night time could be a contributing factor. Light exposure during the night can disrupt a womanaposs circadian rhythm which decreases the release of melatonin - a hormone that preserves theof the placenta and is crucial in securing a successful pregnancy.    Dr Moelenberg Begtrup said: Studies in humans have found lower levels of melatonin mediated by exposure to light-at-night and with no full catch-up during the day among night workers. Melatonin is primarily synthesised in the pineal gland but also in peripheral organs such as the placenta and oies. It plays a role in preserving the optimalof the placenta and experimental studies have demonstrated the importance of tightly regulated circadian rhythms, in which melatonin also has a pivotal role, in the maintenance of successful pregnancies. The study corroborates earlier findings that night work during pregnancy may confer an increased risk of miscarriage and it indicates a lowest observed threshold level of two night shts per week. The new knowledge has relevance for working pregnant women as well as their employers, physicians and midwes. Moreover, the results could have implications for national occupational health regulations.

title: aberdeens mckenna to start for scotland in san marino but shinnie drops to the bench
story: Aberdeen centre-back Scott McKenna has been named in Scotland#s starting line-up to face San Marino in today#s Euro  qualier.McKenna retains his spot as national boss Alex McLeish makes six changes to the side humiliated - in Kazakhstan in the Group I opener on Thursday.Aberdeen skipper Graeme Shinnie, who made his first competitive start in the tie in Kazakhstan, drops to the bench.Having recovered from surgery to a mouth abscess Scotland captain Andy Robertson s to the left back role that was filled by Shinnie in the Group I opener.In defence Stephen O#Donnell comes in at right back in place of Liam Palmer while David Bates remains at centre-back along with McKenna.Former Aberdeen midfielder Kenny McLean has been brought in for John McGinn.Now at Norwich City and pushing for promotion, McLean will make his debut in a competitive game for Scotland.McLean will operate in midfield alongside Stuart Armstrong and Callum McGregor.McLeish has went with an entirely new attack to face the minnows with Callum Paterson set to lead the line with former Aberdeen star Ryan Fraser and Johnny Russell on either wing.

title: aberdeen after school staff criticised leaving child with minibus driver
story: Staff from an Aberdeen after-school club have been criticised for leaving a child alone in a minibus with a driver.The Care Inspectorate watchdog visited the Rising Light After School Club, at the Fountain House on Palmerston Road, Aberdeen, last May and ordered it to make eight improvements after finding a shortage of staff and children not protected from the sun.Inspectors ed on February  and, though they have identied improved staffing levels, they said seven of the eight improvements have not been made.A new report said: “Since the last inspection the service had been successful in recruiting new staff.“We found one child was left in the minibus with the driver while the staff member went into a second school to collect other children.“In order to keep children safe and protect them from harm, children should not be left with anyone who has not been through the safer recruitment process for care and support staff.“A job description for minibus drivers should include clarication that they must not be left alone with the children as they are not care and support staff.”However, the club said its drivers have had safety checks.The report added: “A sun protection policy had been put in place. All staff had completed first aid training.“While there had been some progress made in relation to meeting this requirement further work is required.”The club’s service provider Chris Gbeni said: “We are pleased the report notes the improvements that have been made since last summer and that we have spent extra funds employing more staff.#Our intention is to go above and beyond the expectations by the time of the next report.“All our drivers are safety checked and we should have pushed back on that to the Care Inspectorate once it appeared in their report.”

title: aberdeen pantry project to expand after successful start
story: An innovative Aberdeen food project is set to expand after a successful first six weeks.The Woodside Pantry, run out of the Fersands and Fountain Community Centre, was opened last month.The first of its kind in Scotland, the pantry offers people a cut-price way to shop for food, and is considered as being a possible replacement for food banks.Members pay a £ fee each year to be a part of the project as well as £. for each visit to the pantry.Held on a Tuesday and a Thursday, members are able to get  items of ying quality for their cash, including fresh fruit and vegetables, meat and general household items.The pantry is open to members on a geographical basis, with it initially only being available to a small number of Woodside residents.In just a month, the catchment area increased, with the membership now at .Now, residents from the entirety of Woodside are eligible to take part in the scheme, with the membership set to be capped at .Claire Whyte, a community support worker at the project, said: “We opened on February  and people have been really positive about it.“We’ve just opened it up to the whole of Woodside.“That stretches all the way from the Haudagain roundabout to the Great Northern Hotel so it’s quite a big area.”Food is provided to the pantry from CFine and Fareshare and initial concerns that there may not be enough have been assuaged.Claire said: “We’ve had enough food, which I think could be because we’re the only ones that are doing this.”It’s been so busy at the pantry that Claire and her team are on the lookout for new volunteers.She said: “We’ve been wanting to get in a new batch of volunteers for a while, but I was holding off until the staff that we had got a bit more experience.”

title: aberdeen residents urged to guide new community hub future
story: A call has been made for residents to help run a new Aberdeen community hub.The Tillydrone Community Campus is due to open in the coming months, and members of the public are being urged to come forward to steer the future of the building.The £ million development, built on the site of a former shopping centre, will bring together a range of community services for the people of Tillydrone.It is hoped the Community Management Groupwill be made up of residents who represent ious organisations, including Tillydrone Community Council, the Tilly Network and Aberdeen Lads Club.In the lead-up to the opening of the campus, the CMG will help the council communities team to decide on policies to be implemented at the facility, as well as decide where services will go in the building.Drop-in sessions will be held for people to learn more about what they can do.The events will be held at St George’s Church on Hayton Road in Tillydrone on Tuesday between .am and .am and Wednesday between .pm and pm.Those attending will be able to meet council officers involved in the project, as well as visit the site of the campus.A subsequent event will be held on Saturday between .am and .pm at the church, where members of the group will consider management structures and create a mission statement.Aberdeen City Council regeneration spokesman Gordon Graham said: “We are at an exciting stage of the Tillydrone Community Campus where we’re looking at local people, volunteers and businesses to spearhead the project for the next few years.”Ultimately, it is hoped the CMG can be supported by council staff to develop a business case, which will see the group eventually take over the lease of the hub.As part of a wider three-year plan, the CMG will form a Scottish Charitable Incorporated Organisation .In the second year of existence, the SCIO will create their business plan for the takeover of the campus, before being given the lease in the third year of the plan.

title: clarity urged on hubs
story: A call for clarity has been made over a plan to make savings of more than £, in the delivery of administration, technical and librarian services in Aberdeen#s schools.Aberdeen City Council was faced with making cuts of £. million when councillors met to agree its budget earlier this month.One of the savings agreed by the Labour, Conservative and Independent-led administration involved saving £, by adopting a “hub” model for school technicians, administration staff and librarians.But Alex Nicoll, the SNP group’s resources spokesman, has demanded clarity over the proposals and assurances the move won’t lead to any job losses.He said: “The administration need to come clean as to how this supposed “hub” model for technicians and librarians is actually going to work.“The SNP did not even consider this as an option and it is entirely unclear as to how the administration expect to make such a huge saving without impacting on jobs or making substantial changes to terms and conditions. There is a complete lack of clarity on this matter and there is no doubt that this will be a cause of real concern for the staff themselves – and that is completely unacceptable.“Technicians and librarians play a vital role in our schools and the administration must provide clear answers to explain their entirely unnecessary decision.”Council leaders described the budget as the “worst this city has ever seen” when it was approved, with a raft of savings agreed to help plug the gap, along with increases to charges including council tax, which increased by .%.However, the administration has maintained that jobs are safe and has said it remains committed to its policy of no-compulsory redundancies.Douglas Lumsden, co-leader of Aberdeen City Council, said: “As always the SNP do not like change however this administration recognises that to make the city council governance stronger and fitter for purpose we must work with officers and the trade unions to manage and mitigate change and this saving offers that opportunity.”

title: tickets to see john torode and spencer matthews at taste of grampian set to go on sale
story: The countdown is on for a chance to see celebrity chefs including John Torode in action at this year’s Taste Of Grampian – and fans are being urged to get in fast.Tickets for demonstrations by John and other well-known MasterChef faces such as reality TV star Spencer Matthews and Scotland’s National Chef Gary Maclean are expected to be snapped up when they go on sale on Thursday.Carol Fowler, managing director of Prime Event Management, organisers of Taste Of Grampian, said: “Last year, tickets for James Martin sold out in under an hour. We would encourage people to book their tickets for this year’s celebrities as early as possible to avoid disappointment.”Taste Of Grampian is now Scotland’s biggest one-day food festival and will be held at Inverurie’s Thainstone Centre on Saturday June .Carol said: “We’ve pulled out all the stops to ensure that Taste Of Grampian celebrates its th anniversary in style.“This is one of the best celebrity line-ups we’ve had and we are constantly building and improving the event to keep it fresh and vibrant for the thousands of visitors who attend.”MasterChef judge John will showcase recipes in the main arena with three demonstrations, starting at .am, .pm and concluding with a joint demonstration with his Celebrity MasterChef finalist from , Spencer, at pm.Spencer, of Made In Cha fame, will also hold demonstrations at am and pm.Gary, Scotland’s National Chef and winner of MasterChef: The Professionals in , will be demonstrating Scotch Beef recipes at .am in Ring  and his appearance is sponsored by Quality Meat Scotland.Completing the celebrity line-up is Glasgow-born Helen Vass, who was in the winning team of BBC’s Bake Off Creme de le Creme in . She will be showcasing some delicious patisseries and pastry bakes in Ring  at .pm and .pm.Early bird entry tickets are already on sale for £ at tasteofgrampianearlybirdticket.eventbrite. Gate price on the day will be £.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe latest artist to feature in the Dochas Centre in Lochgilphead is Tarbert#s artist and Argyllshire Advertiser#s contributor, Ann Thomas.Known on the Argyllshire Advertiser#s pages for her thoughtful and humorous depictions of Mid Argyll issues, Ann has been painting and selling images of the shores of Loch Fyne for years.Ann said: #I went to art school, then was a lecturer and got married, and in those days it wasn#t common for a woman to work and be married so I let the painting go for a while, until we found this derelict building that is now the Fyne Gallery.#We did it up and I started painting again and with a printing machine nearby we made a business of selling my paintings called the Ann Rose Thomas gallery: ART Gallery.#Ann#s paintings mostly focus on the water and nature surrounding Loch Fyne.Ann said: #Most of my paintings are bright and cheerful. I like to catch the weather, when the seas are rough, so that mostly means painting in my car, because I like to paint in situation.#Working from a photograph is capturing a moment in time, whereas painting in situation is changing all the time. The lights and the clouds change so the painting evolves as you paint.#The painting, Winter Sparkle on Kilbrannan Sound, hanging above the reception desk at the Dochas Centre is the first thing your eye sets on, and keeps you there with a subtle hint of glitter.#That was a bit tongue in cheek,# Ann said. #I didn#t want it to look like a Christmas card.
